title: Nigel Farage’s Brexit party? Sorry but I’ll be washing my hair | Marina Hyde | Opinion

I strongly suggest readers spend the time to read the article today on racism in football. need to stop kidding ourselves - Britain is a racist country. The racists among us - and there are millions - voted for Brexit.
That does not mean that everyone who voted Leave is a racist, but it does mean that the millions of racists - mainly white English - see Brexit as something that legitimises their beliefs.
Now the Tories are determined to stop us having a vote on whatever Brexit they may manage to get parliament to finally let through.
Pretty obvious why. Many of the millions of racists are Conservative Party members or voters.

title: Nigel Farage pledges to deliver UK into promised land of bankruptcy | Politics
content:
Christopher Isherwood the 1950s travel writer, gay and bon viveur, cousin of the Berkhamsted Greenes, reported a Peruvian politician who got real erotic pleasure from delivering his speeches. I should think Farage specializes in killing any joy at all, but I did meet one Greek woman in UK politics in the 1970s who was very similar in brushing up her legs and so forth with the utmost gusto to make her political point. One hears also, (not something i have ever tried) of the politician who focuses his attention on one woman in the audience to the exlcuson of all others, in order to get to home base, so to speak with the good lady after the meeting. It may bemore of a theatrical/ pop music skill than anything which would explain the groupies at the stage door of the big rock concerts, although even that may be a thing of the past.
Who Farage's groupies are, I cant imagine either, but he is such a special statuesque, unique person that there cant be many women who would not easily be lured by him. It is his Napoleonic stature, and his similar ambition, more than anything. Think of the Empress Josephine.

The second was at Glastonbury when I managed to persuade my partner to see him instead of stevie wonder! There were about 20 people on the tent and he was so messed up that he repeated the first 15 minutes of his set word for word including a joke that mixed up racist with rapist that bombed hard both times but he stuck to his guns and it was really surreal seeing it play out

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: Dating sites and pubs are not the only places to meet people. I found that joining clubs, classes, local societies all helped. And go along to your church, not necessarily to the services (unless you wish) but they hold coffee mornings and musical evenings too. You may not necessarily meet a man immediately, but will definitely get to know people, and these people may eventually introduce you to somebody you can begin a relationship with.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: You sound like someone who's at peace with herself, and I'd say that's something to be proud of. Ask yourself what falling in love with a man would give you, that you do not already have. Don't get me wrong, I'm not against relationships perse. Indeed, for 25 years now I've been a happily married man. But craving something without really knowing how it would enrich your life? If you feel that you have to, then go for it, but I'd be very careful.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
Go for friendship first. Then if you laugh together and enjoy common pursuits maybe there could more to it. There's no such thing as coincidence. You have a good sense of humour. use and it and see what responses you get
Good luck

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: My situation is somewhat different. I'm a 70-year-old male (in Germany) who has always had issues to meet a woman, since I have Asperger's. And of course I know that everyone's circumstances are unique and not comparable. Well, meanwhile I try to take things with humour and say that I'm "beyond good and bad".

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
Let’s not diminish how incredibly hard it is when all around you seem to be living the 2.4 dream and you’re not. We’re social creatures designed to pair up.
Sometimes the right person is late - they’ve been trying to make a difficult relationship work rather than leaving, they’ve been pursuing their career, they’ve been getting their act together, they’ve been stuck in an ice cave in Antarctica, they simply haven’t found you yet.
They’ll show up eventually - usually at a really inconvenient moment.
In the meantime, maybe think about some counselling to help work out why you spent so much of your time in pursuit of pretty boys who let you down and what you really want from a mature, loving relationship.
I’m guessing you’re probably now so wary of getting into another bad situation that you’re subconsciously avoiding good situations and having a chat with someone who will help boost your confidence may work wonders.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: Firstly, this is a really tough, although sadly a thoroughly common issue with successful, grounded and independent women. I understand entirely your predicament. A close friend of mine, successful, well travelled, funny, was determined to meet and find love - and she did! She married 2 years ago in a beautiful Lake District lodge - so it can happen. How did she do it? With patience, perseverance and lots of first dates. She chose an online dating website that reflected her ideals and just stuck with it. You may say - I can't stand online dating - (I hear you and have given up many times myself on this ) I guess the lesson there is like you I am still single, why? Because I am not putting any effort into it - so don't do as I do and be more focussed perhaps?! Lots of luck. M

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: I met my partner online...I'm 62 she's 58, we live separately thus retaining our much valued independence, but we love each others company and spend several days and nights a month together. There are decent men and women out there, but you have to work at it and be utterly honest about what you want. The only advice I can offer you is to persist. Oh...and at 46 you are far too young to be writing yourself off in relationship terms.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: It's not a new suggestion but sometimes the pressure is off if you don't overtly seek out a partner via dating sites, bars etc. But you can still use clubs, the internet with local places, and societies of all types although preferably one that has interests that you might like. There are other ways of meeting a potential lover than through the obvious channels. Good luck and stay optimistic!

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: What I find is that many dating people want to keep the benefits of their singledom but have someone who fits in with them. In other words a lot of people are looking for a relationship but only on their terms! Relationships really need a bit of input, a bit of self sacrifice, from both parties, to work.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
Remember that you never find anything by looking so hard for it.
It will find you when you're not looking.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
I was you a few years ago (just turned 50). I started thinking that, well if this is my life it could be worse. Too bad I never got someone to love me enough to stick with me.
Then I started seeing these Facebook posts of a fan club. I decided to join. Then I started travelling on my own to include places where some of my new friends lived. And met them.
And on one of my trips I sat down on a terras and this man started to talk to me. And we met again the next day. And one thing lead to another but he wasn't my type! I had to talk to myself to at least try and find out where this was going. We've been together for 1,5 years now.
What I'm saying is, take yourself out of your safety zone. Make mistakes. And give people a chance you would never have given a chance to before. People look at us and see an odd couple. But I've never been so happy and I never cared less what others say.
So open yourself up to coincidence. Give people a chance. Take a chance and make a risk.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: This is speculation based on the scant information you offer, but if you're really fun, nice, and not bad looking, are there really no men interested in you? Or have you dismissed them as being beneath your notice, because when you were younger, you dated good-looking men? There's probably some guy in your immediate circle, who's also fun. nice, and not bad looking, who quietly worships you, but whom you've discounted because you still have some unfulfilled pretty boy fantasy from your youth.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
I met my partner, and love of my life, when I was 41 and he was 57. He said he had given up on love after a series of long and short relationships over the years, until I inserted myself into his life. Now , 12 years on, he says he is the happiest he has ever been in his life. So message one is you are way too young to think love has left you behind.
Message two is do things you enjoy that get you out there. Meet ups can be great for doing things that you enjoy in mixed groups, also activities and evening classes - but make sure to pick ones that will have the gender of your choice attending also. I personally don’t think pubs and nightclubs are a good way to meet friends and lovers, especially when alcohol may be a factor. These are places for casual hook ups, but not good grazing grounds for more serious relationships. So get out there doing some fun old and new hobbies, and see who you meet. From hiking, to sports, to book reading, debating, philosophy or language arts type evening classes. The bonus is you have a great time and learn stuff or exercise even if you don’t meet the special one , so nothing is lost. Good luck and enjoy the adventure.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: A female colleague took out a paid membership in a mate-finding agency and ended up marrying one of the candidates. If the agency is reputable a background check will be done so you will be reasonably certain the people you meet will not be criminals, married, or otherwise misrepresenting themselves. It may be expensive, but perhaps have a better chance of success.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content: I wouldn't advise mentioning any of this at interview or during your probation period though.

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
The impression I get, and I may be wrong, is that you are looking for a relationship rather than looking to connect with people. I speak from self-awareness. When I go out to bar nights/comedy nights, most of them designed for dating, I have the 'eye out' and I think people can sense it. I reckon it can be off-putting because it's like putting up a sign/barrier which says 'potentials only please'.
You

title: I’m 46 and would like to meet a man and fall in love | Life and style
content:
Keep trying dating sites.
It’s a numbers game. All I can advise is that you go for friendship and see if anything else grows from that.

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion
content: I'm truly surprised to see how few people there are here who are not more committed to disentangling themselves from the highly anti-democratic political structure that is the European Union. The kind of collectivism so keenly embraced by so many here has been tried before in the twentieth century, and at great cost of human lives, and I can only assume the reason the ideology is gaining traction again is because it is being considered through a post-modern filter that for many, screens the folly of catastrophic Marxist dogma. It's okay for the supporters, they'll be dead by the time the real rot sets in, but their grandchildren will suffer, have no doubt.

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion
content: OK, I'm bored with this poetry slanging match, can we get back to all out civil war?

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion

It also fails to mention that his glorious career in the T.A.-" I was a soldier, I wasn't trained to lose"- was in the Catering Corp. In Rayleigh you could probably put up a pig's bladder on a stick with a blue rosette and it'd win for the Tories.

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion
content:
"The Brexiteers incanted a mixture of the first and second world wars to generate a mythical Britain"
I never heard any Brexiters talk like that. They all talk about demcoracy and sovereignty. True, some point out that people died in defence of our vote while remainers casually suggest it should be ignored. Little doubt which side many of them would be one in the era of the the levellers, the chartists or the suffragettes. I heard a woman last night saying Brexiters were "ahistorical" for referring to "liberation" and colonialism. There's irony, Brexit is a demand for a little bit more democracy and self determination, it is incredibly modest in historical terms. Yet the reaction to it is just as hysterical as the reaction to the suffragettes or the reaction to those fighting colonialism. Brexiters want to re-instate parliamentary sovereignty not otherthrow it. But the reaction to it is like the furious reaction of the British to the Mau Mau uprising in Kenya.
It is the idea of democracy that strikes terror into their hearts.

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion

title: There are dark stirrings in Brexiteers’ sudden fixation with poetry | Edward Sugden | Opinion
content: In the main, the people on here who are banging on about the Empire or the War, Spitfires, past glories etc. are Remainers using it as a way of denigrating Leave voters as backwards looking. Idiotic politicians will use any means of rhetoric to support their views, but I have literally heard noone in real life talking about such stuff.

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content:
Scotland wants independence from the UK, which is impossible for the country if it is outside the EU. NI voted to Remain in order to keep its border with the RoI open.
Can you not see why they voted the way they did?
Londoners on the other hand have separated from the rest of the UK for selfish reasons alone. It suits them to rely on financial services and to hell with our former manufacturing base.

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content: Precisely. Nothing other than divisive neoliberal propaganda.

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content: Comments on this article will close at 17:15 BST. Thank you for your contributions.

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content:
Yes, as a rule, if you live in a small town rather than a major city, you are generally more likely to have conservative attitudes to issues like immigration and the welfare state, and to have voted leave in the 2016 EU referendum. And, again generally, the opposite is true of residents of major urban areas. Yet to view superficial characteristics of the place in which one lives as a reliable indicator of one’s political attitudes is to invent a counterproductive, unnecessary divide.
So you also agree that the cliche , generalisation is true . I don't see why pointing out this truism is dangerous surely ignoring is dangerous .

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content: The political debate over the past 3 years has certainly lacked nuance. Well written article, though I doubt it will make a difference to those whose agenda suits the divisive stereotyping.

title: The left-behind v the metropolitan elite? That's a lazy, harmful cliche | Luke Cartledge | Opinion
content:
Pretty hilarious hearing remain extremists bitch about cliches :-) Fuck me, the remain camp has broken the mould when it comers to lazy thinking, stereotyping 17.5 million Leave voters. Luke cry me a river,
Its no myth that 60% of Labour seats voted Leave. Its a fact. But instead of addressing the issues and seeing how to bring those folks into the folks, Luke says there is no problem, so we can completely ignore it. Move right along.

title: Halloween Brexit is a fitting outcome for the zombie prime minister | John Crace | UK news
content:
I personally don't think it was lack of information, I think was lack of definition as to what was meant by leave.
Did everyone who voted leave expect to void the GFA?
Did they all vote to put the unity of the UK in jeopardy?
How about decimating most industries exporting products to the EU?
Risk UK agriculture?
Shift the UK farther in to a service based economy?
No one bothered to spell out what leave was and Leave campaigners peddled all sorts of options including joining EFTA, the Canada+ deal (I think some now mention Canada ++); Possibly the least mentioned was the chaotic no deal, which looks like one of the front runners at the moment.
